1.1	DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Sunoco, LLC is located in Birmingham, Alabama.   The facility is an independent wholesale distributor of ethanol and petroleum-based refined products.    Operation of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) covered processes involves the use or handling of certain listed regulated substances as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in 40 CFR Part 68.  Currently, the regulated substances at the site are butane, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide.

Butane is stored in a pressurized bullet tank with a maximum rated capacity of 126,360 pounds (lbs).  Butane is used as a seasonal blending component in gasoline.

Anhydrous Ammonia is stored in a pressurized bullet tank with a maximum rated capacity of 2,000 gallons (10,300 lbs).  An administrative control will be placed on the tank restricting it to an 80 percent fill (1,600 gallons or 8,240 lbs).

Sulfur Dioxide is stored in a pressurized bullet tank with a maximum rated capacity of 8,000 gallons (96,000 lbs).  An administrative control will be placed on the tank restricting it to a 60 percent fill (4,800 gallons or 55,152 lbs).

The facility coordinates as measured by the front gate entrance are latitude 33.449350 and longitude -86.877961 decimal degrees; the facility coordinates as measured at the butane tank are latitude 33.451433 and longitude -86.875966; the facility coordinates as measured at the anhydrous ammonia tank are latitude 33.458434 and longitude -86.877097; and the facility coordinates as measured at the sulfur dioxide tank are latitude 33.458434 and longitude -86.877097.  

1.2	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE PRACTICES AND PROGRAMS

The facility accidental release prevention and response practices and programs are designed to protect the employees, contractors, visitors, the general public and the environment.  Our commitment is demonstrated through the way we conduct daily business to safely maintain and

operate the facility and prevent chemical releases.  In the event that a release does occur, both mitigation systems and procedures are in place to support and provide the foundation to prevent, control and minimize the impact of the event.  In addition to these safety systems and protocols, well trained employees and contractors take active roles in key design, maintenance and operational programs intended to operate the process and prevent releases.   In the event of a release, emergency response procedures are in place to minimize any impacts.


2.0	HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS

A hazard assessment was performed to analyze releases for potential impacts to the surrounding community and environment.  These assessments consist of determining "worst case" and "alternative case" scenarios as specified by the EPA.  Since the facility is a Program 3 source, and because of the site lay out, one "worst case" and one "alternative case" scenario have been selected.

The Worst Case Scenario (WCS) inputs are presented on Table 1, Appendix B, Tables followed by supporting calculations.  The Alternative Case Scenario (ACS) inputs are presented on Table 2 followed by supporting calculations.  Following is a description and summary of conclusions for the analysis.

2.1	WORST CASE SCENARIO (WCS) DESCRIPTIONS

Per the criteria described by EPA, a "worst case" scenario event was selected for:

¿	Butane tank rupture - flammable gas
¿	Anhydrous Ammonia (Ammonia) tank rupture - toxic gas
¿	Sulfur Dioxide tank rupture - toxic gas.
 
As previously mentioned administrative controls are in place for Ammonia (80% fill limit) and Sulfur Dioxide (60% fill limit).  Furthermore, the Ammonia and Sulfur Dioxide tanks have secondary containment (passive measures) for which no credit was taken into account to demonstrate the conservative nature of the calculations.   
The worst case scenarios selected are described below:

FLAMMABLE WORST CASE SCENARIO:

Butane Release -

The

regulated flammable substance release of butane is the worst case scenario.  Butane is a product stored in a pressurized bullet tank inside the gates of the facility.  The release was modeled using EPA's conservative Risk Management Program Guidance for Off-site Consequence Analysis (March 2009) (PDF) Table 13.  The model assumes the total quantity of butane is released into a vapor cloud and that a vapor cloud explosion results.  

The impact area is the distance to an endpoint to an overpressure level of 1 pound per square inch (psi).  Assuming this tank catastrophically fails and releases a total maximum inventory of 126,360 lbs of butane, the distance to the overpressure endpoint for this event is 0.43 miles.  Note that EPA considers these distances to endpoints as approximations.

TOXIC WORST-CASE SCENARIO:

Anhydrous Ammonia Release - 

The regulated toxic gas release of anhydrous ammonia is the worst case scenario.  Anhydrous Ammonia is a product stored as a gas liquefied under pressure (bullet tank) inside the gates of the facility.  The release was modeled using EPA's conservative Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009) (PDF) Table 7.  The model assumes the following:

¿	total quantity of ammonia (8,240 pounds) is released from the tank over a 10-minute period, equating to 824 pounds per minute release rate
¿	ammonia is a neutrally buoyant gas stored in an urban area
¿	a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second
¿	toxic endpoint of 200 parts per million ammonia (0.14 mg/l).

Assuming this tank catastrophically fails and releases a total maximum inventory of 8,240 lbs of ammonia (80% fill max), the distance to the toxic endpoint (200 ppm) for this event is 1.12 miles.  Note that EPA considers these distances to endpoints as approximations. 

Sulfur Dioxide Release - 

The regulated toxic gas release of Sulfur Dioxide is the worst case scenario.  Sulfur Dioxide is a product stored in a pressurized bullet tan

k inside the gates of the facility.  The release was modeled using EPA's conservative Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009) (PDF) Table 7.

The model assumes:

¿	total quantity of sulfur dioxide (55,152 pounds) is released from the tank over a 10-minute period
¿	sulfur dioxide is a dense gas stored in an urban area
¿	a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second
¿	toxic endpoint of 3 parts per million ammonia (0.0078 mg/l).

Assuming this tank catastrophically fails and releases a total maximum inventory of 55,152 lbs of sulfur dioxide (80% fill max), the distance to the toxic endpoint (3 ppm) for this event is 23.61miles.  Note that EPA considers these distances to endpoints as conservative approximations.

Due to the extensive length of the endpoint distance utilizing EPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis, another EPA model (ALOHA) was used to check the toxic endpoint distance and the affected population.  ALOHA estimated the toxic endpoint at 3.5 miles and with winds coming from the WSW the affected population is 22,396.


2.2	ALTERNATIVE CASE SCENARIO (ACS) DESCRIPTIONS

Per the criteria described by EPA, an "alternative case" scenario event was selected for:

¿	Butane tank  - flammable gas;
¿	Anhydrous Ammonia (Ammonia) tank - toxic gas; and
¿	Sulfur Dioxide tank - toxic gas.
The Alternate case scenarios for each tank assumed lifting of a pressure relief valve (PRV).  This scenario was covered in the process hazard analysis (PHA) for each of the referenced chemicals.  The alternate case scenario selected is described below for each chemical:

FLAMMABLE ACS:

Butane Pressure Relief Valve Lift-

An over pressurization of the butane tank causes a 2.5-inch PRV on the tank to relieve to atmosphere over a 3-hour period resulting in the release of 3,528 pounds of butane.  Alternatively, three PRVs on the tank could simultaneously relieve for 1 hour and have the same resulting release of 3,528 pounds of butane.

Calculations assumed that the PRV behaves as an orifice venting to atmosphere.  The release was modeled using EPA's conservative Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009) (PDF) Table 13.  The model assumes the total quantity of butane is released into a vapor cloud and that a vapor cloud explosion results.  The impact area is the distance to an endpoint to an overpressure level of 1 psi.  Based on these assumptions, the distance to the overpressure endpoint for this event is 0.1 miles.  Note that EPA considers these distances to endpoints as conservative approximations.
TOXIC ACS:

Anyhydrous Ammonia Relief Valve Lift -

An over pressurization of the anhydrous ammonia tank causes a 2.25-inch PRV on the tank to relieve to atmosphere over a 1-hour period resulting in the release of 514 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Alternatively, two PRVs on the tank could simultaneously relieve for 1 hour and have the same resulting release of 514 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  This equates to a 8.56 pound per minute release rate.  Calculations assumed that the PRV behaves as an orifice venting to atmosphere.  The release was modeled using EPA's conservative Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009) (PDF) Table 9.  The distance to the toxic endpoint (200 ppm) for this event is 0.10 miles.  Note that EPA considers these distances to endpoints as conservative approximations.

Sulfur Dioxide Relief Valve Lift -

An over pressurization of the sulfur dioxide tank causes a 2.25-inch PRV on the tank to relieve to atmosphere over a 1-hour period resulting in the release of 514 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Alternatively, two PRVs on the tank could simultaneously relieve for 1 hour and have the same resulting release of 789 pounds of sulfur dioxide.  This equates to a 13.15 pound per minute release rate.  Calculations assumed that the PRV behaves as an orifice venting to atmosphere.  The release was modeled usin

g EPA's conservative Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (March 2009) (PDF) Table 7.  The distance to the toxic endpoint (3 ppm) for this event is 0.26 miles.  Note that EPA considers these distances to endpoints as conservative approximations. 

2.3	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

At Sunoco, LLC, numerous plans exist to promote process safety management.  Some of these plans include Operation and Maintenance manual, Process Safety Management plan, Fire Safety Analysis plan and the Risk Management Plan.  These plans are designed to protect the employees, public and environment and to prevent accidents from occurring.   Sunoco, LLC has not experienced any accidents involving the butane tank over the last five years.


3.0	GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM STEPS

3.1	EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Company employees are encouraged to actively participate in accident prevention at Sunoco, LLC.  Employee participation in these efforts is accomplished on several levels both formally and informally.  Below are specific procedures and programs implemented at the facility: 

¿	Quarterly Safety Meetings
¿	Behavioral Based Safety (BBS) program
¿	Employee Safety Suggestion Program
¿	Process Hazard Analyses (PHA)
¿	Job Safety Analyses (JSA) 
¿	Injury and Illness Prevention Plan.

Quarterly Safety Meetings are held with employees.  The purpose is to elevate safety awareness of all employees through activities, organized meetings, review accident investigations, review inspection reports, safe work practices etc.  The end result desired is to achieve a reduction of risky behaviors associated with incidents and injuries both on and off the job.   Formal safety meetings are supplemented by "toolbox talks" of 10 to 15 minutes that are done at the start of a work shift or at other times designated by the supervisor.

BBS Periodic Safety Field Visits are performed by salaried and hourly employees to provide informal forums for discussi

on of safe job performance and concerns.   Potential safety concerns are identified while a job is in progress and addressed before they result in injuries or near misses.

The Employee Safety Suggestion Program is designed to provide another avenue for employees to voice any safety issues.  

The Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) is conducted by a team of Sunoco employees and may be led by an outside consultant or an internal employee.  At a minimum, the Sunoco team always consists of members representing maintenance and operations. Other employees and contract personnel with specialized expertise may be called in to participate on an as needed basis. (See Section 3.3 Process Hazard Analyses for more detail.)

A Job Safety Analyses (JSA) is a technique utilized by employees to break a small or large job into its basic steps before performing the work.  Each step is analyzed to identify potential hazards that may cause an injury.  Safe work practices are then identified to prevent the potential injury identified while the work is performed.

The Injury and Illness Prevention Plan details how plant management and employees will reduce incident risk through a combination of proper work planning,  engineering controls, inspections, personal protection equipment (PPE) and promptly and thoroughly investigating accidents and near-miss situations to determine the root causes and to correct the problem in order to prevent recurrences.    
 
3.2	PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

At Sunoco, many written documents are available which provide guidance on how to safely operate the various processes within the plant. The documents related to process safety information are utilized for training of employees and contractors to identify and understand the hazards associated with each process.  The documents are also utilized as a resource when conducting process hazards analyses, and are utilized as a reference during unit operations.

This documentation consists of information

pertaining to:

¿	Chemical hazards [i.e. Safety Data Sheets (SDS)]
¿	Process technology (drawings, process descriptions, etc.)
¿	Equipment in the process.

The written documentation for chemical hazards is addressed through the use of SDS for butane, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide.  SDS are maintained on the facility server which can be accessed by the terminal personnel 24 hours per day and 7 days per week.   Specific chemical information describing the toxicity, reactivity, corrosively, etc. is included in each SDS.  In addition, information pertinent to emergency response and first aid treatment for various routes of exposure is provided.

Many technical documents are maintained to provide information to employees concerning the technology of the process.  The technology of the process is documented through process flow diagrams [Operations and Maintenance (O&M) Manual], process overviews, unit mechanical data books, and operating procedures.  All of these documents are readily available to employees on a daily basis and are utilized in initial and refresher training of company employees and contractors.

Many technical documents, policies and procedures are maintained to provide information to employees concerning the equipment in the process.   This information includes, but is not limited to:

¿	Process flow diagrams or piping and instrument diagrams (Figure 8, Process Flow Diagrams, Appendix A)
¿	Materials of construction
¿	Relief systems
¿	Safety systems [e.g. emergency shut-off valves (ESVs), etc.]
¿	O&M manual
¿	Fire safety analysis plan.
  
These types of documents provide technical information including materials of construction, electrical ratings, design codes and standards, relief system and safety system design.   These technical documents combined with written and implemented maintenance and inspection procedures performed by highly trained personnel assist in assuring that equipment is installed and operated as designed.

3.3	PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSES

Sunoco utilizes PHAs (as detailed in Injury & Illness Prevention Plan) to ensure that controls are in place to minimize, manage and control hazards that may potentially affect both on-site and off-site personnel and the environment. By reviewing hazards associated with anticipatable changes in the process, PHAs are designed to assist in identifying operability problems, safety issues and environmental concerns, and the associated causes, consequences, safeguards and risks.  In addition to performing PHAs that are triggered by changes, PHAs are also performed to revalidate unit PHAs at least every five years. 

The primary style of PHA used within Sunoco for both initial and revalidation PHAs is the "What if" checklist technique.  However, Sunoco may use other techniques such as the hazard and operability study (HAZOP) when it is determined that a more detailed analysis is required by the change.  The PHA is conducted by a team of Sunoco employees and may be led by an outside consultant or a site employee.  At a minimum, the Sunoco team always consists of members representing maintenance and operations.  Other employees and contract personnel with specialized expertise may be called in to participate on an as needed basis.  The PHA team identifies and evaluates potential hazards and any environmental, safety, and operational concerns which may have a deleterious affect either on site or off site.  Depending on the likelihood of a hypothesized event or process change and the seriousness of the consequences, actions are formulated by the PHA team, which are presented to plant management to review and address as necessary.  Actions/recommendations are intended to improve process design, improve operability and improve safety.  

Plant management will in turn assign each action to individuals with the experience and knowledge to address and close out each action.  Depending on the potential impact of the 

hazard identified, target

completion dates are established for implementing the approved changes.  A copy of the PHA's and accompanying documentation for each chemical is include in Appendix D, Process Hazard Analysis.

3.4	OPERATING PROCEDURES

Sunoco has a fully developed set of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for the covered processes within the plant.   These operating procedures have been developed to be consistent with process safety information, and are maintained as such through annual reviews by operating personnel.  For the butane tank system, the O&M Manual covers operating steps such as initial startup, normal operations and delivery, shutdowns, evacuation of the tank and emergency procedures.  For the anhydrous ammonia system, the supplier (Tanner Industries) provides a "Customer Manual" provides detailed information regarding physical/chemical properties, withdrawal, electrical connections, product withdrawal, piping systems, maintenance, leaks, inspections, and other operational information.  For sulfur dioxide, the O&M Manual covers operating steps such as initial start up, normal operation, delivery and emergency procedures for the sulfur dioxide tank, pump and vaporizing system.

Other operations procedures also cover safety and health considerations along with specific procedures located at the unit.  Written procedures address all aspects listed by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and the RMP regulations.   

3.5	TRAINING

Sunoco has a comprehensive training program in place for employees involved in operating the plant.  This program is designed to address the needs of new employees and experienced operators.  The Injury and Illness Prevention Plan outlines specific training which includes but is not limited to PPE, job specific training, emergency response, chemical hazard information, lock-out/tag-out etc.  Sunoco utilizes both classroom and on the job training.  Competency testing is done

in the form of observation and written testing.  All records of training are recorded and maintained at the Plant.

All PSM/RMP affected employees are properly trained in all areas of handling highly hazardous materials and in the processes that use such materials. This training is further outlined in the Process Safety Management Procedure. 

3.6	CONTRACTORS

Contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialized work on or adjacent to a covered process must meet certain training and safety performance requirements as described in Sunoco's Process Safety Management Program procedure.  Before awarding a contract, the Administrator or designated personnel will screen and evaluate the job skills, methods, safety performance, certifications, and safety programs of any contractors being considered for maintenance, repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or around a process covered under this Program.  If a contract company is awarded work by Sunoco, their employees' performance and continued qualification while on site are periodically monitored to ensure that company standards are met on an on-going basis.

Section 5.5 of Sunoco's O&M Manual stipulates the policy for maintenance work on the RMP regulated processes (butane, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide) performed by either employees or contractors.  Individuals performing maintenance on the RMP regulated processes are trained in the hazards of the system.   Personnel conducting testing procedures applicable to the system or equipment that they are working are trained on that system.  All maintenance contractors must also attend a general site health and safety training administered by the Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) Manager (or designee) prior to commencing their work.

3.7	PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW (PSSR)

As required by OSHA and EPA regulations and in keeping with good operating practice, Sunoco conducts pre-startup safety reviews wh

the various types of anticipatable emergencies that might occur at the plant:

¿	Emergency Response Procedures
¿	Emergency Action Plan (EAP)
¿	Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan
¿	Process Safety Management 
¿	Fire Safety Analysis Plan (FSA)
¿	O&M Manual (Butane Bulk Storage Tank System)
¿	Customer Manual (Anhydrous Ammonia Bulk Storage Tank System)
¿	O&M Manual ( Sulfur Dioxide Bulk Storage Tank System)

The plant emergency response plan has specific procedures on what to do during and emergencies for the covered process including emergency contact information for the fire department and evacuation procedures.

For butane tank system, Sunoco has coordinated with the local Fire Department (See Fire Safety Analysis).  The FSA plan details specific emergency devices and equipment such a location of emergency shut off valves, fire suppression equipment and hydrants.    It also summarizes the local fire departments ability to respond to a butane system fire, and utilizing plume stabilizers and suppressors.  Per the plan, the Birmingham Fire and Rescue Service could respond in less than six minutes should an emergency occur.   The FSA is periodically updated and shared with local fire department as needed.

For the ammonia tank system, safety and operational procedures will be followed in accordance with the Compressed Gas Association procedure ANSI CGA G-2.1-2014.  Furthermore, the facility is equipped with both stationary and handheld sensors to ensure the safety of all personnel in the event of an emergency.

For the sulfur dioxide system, safety and operational procedures will be followed in accordance with the Compressed Gas Association procedure ANSI CGA G-3-1995.  Furthermore, the facility is equipped with both stationary and handheld sensors to ensure the safety of all personnel in the event of an emergency.

Sunoco, LLC further coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) by reporting when required any ha

en a modification to a process is significant enough to change process safety information.  As an integral part of our Management of Change (MOC) process and as outlined in the PSM procedure, a PSSR ensures that operability, design parameters, environmental concerns and safety issues are met prior to commissioning the change.  It also ensures that all employees and contractors affected by the change are notified and/or trained prior to commissioning the change.  Where necessary, field verification occurs to ensure that actual construction meets the design standards specified in the MOC.  If the change were determined to be too extensive or complex for a PSSR, a PHA would be performed in addition to a PSSR.

 
3.8	MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

Sunoco has practices and procedures such as the Process Safety Management procedure in place to ensure that equipment has been designed, constructed, installed and maintained to contain the chemicals in the process. Any equipment or system used to store, 

process and handle highly hazardous chemicals is included in the mechanical integrity program.  Also, any other process equipment, safety equipment and backup safety systems used to minimize the impact of a release are included in the program. 

Mechanical components and systems including pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, piping components, relief systems, vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, safety equipment, monitoring devices, pumps, etc. are maintained through:

¿	Written procedures
¿	Training
¿	Inspection and testing (when needed)
¿	Safely/quickly correcting equipment deficiencies.

Written procedures supply the guidance necessary to correctly repair, install and perform maintenance on critical equipment in a consistent, safe manner. 

Maintenance and inspection personnel will be trained and qualified to understand and follow the preventive maintenance program procedures, safe practices, and the proper use and application of special equipmen

t or unique tools that may be required to ensure the mechanical integrity of all equipment and processes.

Both the type and frequency of initial and on-going inspection and testing of equipment are based on applicable codes, standards, and/or manufacturer's recommendations.  Any equipment deficiencies found as a result of inspection and testing of equipment are made in a safe and timely manner.

Quality assurance is an integral part of mechanical integrity.  Throughout all aspects of this element, the mechanical integrity program provides appropriate checks and balances to assure that equipment, spare parts, maintenance materials are installed properly, meet design specifications and follow manufacturer's instructions.  It is the plant policy that spare parts or equipment for the butane, anhydrous ammonia or sulfur dioxide tanks are purchased only from a qualified pressure vessel parts dealer.
3.9	HOT-WORK

Sunoco has many safe work practices in place to safely perform job tasks in or near plant process areas.  A key practice in preventing unsafe events is the site hot-work program.   Hot-work operations on or near a covered process can only begin after a Hot-work permit has been issued.  Hot-work permits cover welding, cutting, or any other spark or heat producing operations in or near the covered process.   Only the site Administrator or their designee can authorize a hot-work permit.  The hot-work permit procedure includes a list of hazards that must be identified and details compliance with fire prevention and protection requirements.   The hot-work permit includes the following:

¿	The date authorized for hot work
¿	The object on which the hot work is to be performed
¿	Identification of  openings, cracks, and holes where sparks may drop to combustible materials below
¿	Description of fire extinguishers required to handle fires that are of an incipient type.
¿	Assignment of fire watchers for locations where more than a minor fire could potentially

develop
¿	Description of precautions associated with combustible materials on floors, walls, partitions, ceilings, or roofs of combustible construction
¿	Prohibition on welding or cutting in unauthorized areas, in buildings with sprinkler systems while such protection is impaired, in explosive atmospheres, and in storage areas for large quantities of readily ignitable materials
¿	Requires relocation of combustibles where practicable and cover with flameproof covers where not practicable
¿	Identification for shutdown of any ducts or conveyor systems that may convey sparks to distant combustibles.

These practices and others along with proper training of employees and contractors ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

3.10	MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE AUTHORIZATION (MOCA)

The plant's Process Safety Management procedure describes how the MOCA is implemented at Sunoco, LLC.   The procedure provides a system to thoroughly evaluate a process change as it relates to chemicals handled or processed, design or technology, equipment use or maintenance, procedures for operation and changes to ancillary facilities affected by the process.  The procedure as practiced assures that the following are addressed prior to a change:

¿	Technical basis
¿	Actual or potential impact on employee safety and health
¿	Effects of temporary changes
¿	Operating procedure modifications
¿	Employee, contractor notification and training
¿	Management authorization/approval requirements.

Changes (except for "replacement in kind" changes) are evaluated and the complexity is also assessed to determine whether a PSSR is required, or if a more in-depth PHA is appropriate.  If a PSSR or a PHA is required, employees are assigned task(s) to:

¿	Update process information or maintenance schedules or procedures
¿	Provide employee and/or contractor training
¿	Revise operating procedures
¿	Compose and implement new safety procedures as appropriate, etc.

When

required, all of the above actions are performed before the change is commissioned through the final PSSR.  A PHA, if performed, would identify additional action items to be addressed many of which would also have to be addressed prior to startup of the change in the process.

This procedure assures that all information involved in all elements and aspects of PSM and RMP are managed and kept current.  Through this system, all necessary documentation is updated, temporary changes are tracked, approvals are obtained and all responsibilities for each MOCA is assigned to individuals and tracked to completion.

3.11	INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

A written incident investigation and reporting guideline (Process Safety Management) has been developed and implemented by plant management. This guideline formalizes the process by which an accident must be reported and can be investigated by employees (and contractors when appropriate) to determine the direct and/or contributing causes of an incident.  Both types of causes are used to help formulate corrective action(s) intended to prevent the possibility of a reoccurrence of the specific accident or a similar event.   Draft reports of the incident are prepared for the Management Team Investigation (MTI).   

Findings and corrective actions are reviewed by plant management.  Any approved corrective actions are assigned to appropriate plant personnel for their follow-up and completion.

3.12	EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE

The plant's programs and capabilities for emergency planning and response are discussed in detail in a later section of this plan.

3.13	COMPLIANCE AUDITS

It is the company's policy to conduct an audit at least every three years on the elements of OSHA's PSM standard and EPA's RMP regulation. This will assure that the procedures and practices developed are adequate and are being followed.  Various employees including hourly and salaried employees participate in the audit by gathering required docum

entation, researching requested documentation, verifying information and participating in interviews.  All audits results, future or current pertaining to the two most recent OSHA PSM audits will be fully documented and kept on file.  The filed documents include the protocol of the audit and the results of the audit in which all deficiencies are recorded, assigned to qualified employees and tracked to completion.


4.0	CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Accident Prevention Programs described above ensure the safe operations and management of the chemical hazards.  In addition to these programs and procedures, there are safety systems and equipment installed in the plant to provide various levels of safety.  The levels of safety include:

1)	Prevention
2)	Quick detection
3)	Containment/control
4)	Mitigation.

Specific safety features used in various processes are described below:
¿	Release prevention 
1.	Emergency Shut off Valve 
2.	Remote Emergency Shutoff valve (Butane tank only)
3.	Butane, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide tanks have valves designed to close during rapid flow situations.

¿	Release detection 
1.	24 -hour manned operation
2.	Periodic walk through by trained personnel.

¿	Release containment/control 
1.	Process safety valves that discharge to vent back to the tank system
2.	Atmospheric relief devices 
3.	Manual and automatic valves to isolate chemical releases
4.	Emergency shutdown systems. 

¿	Release mitigation 
1.	Site personnel trained in emergency response procedures
2.	Fire suppression provided through the use of portable 20 pound dry chemical ABC extinguisher and fire hydrants 
3.	Facility and emergency equipment access is maintained by keeping roadways clear of blockages should outside emergency response be needed.


5.0	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

5.1	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

The plant has a comprehensive set of emergency procedures consisting of several plans which have been written to address

zardous or extremely hazardous chemicals that may be on-site over the Threshold Planning Quantity (TPQ) through the annual Tier II EPCRA reporting process.  The LEPC uses this information to develop community response plans in event of an emergency.

Since coordination occurs between the site and local fire department for emergencies on the butane, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide covered processes, the remaining sections of §68.95 Emergency Response do not apply at this time, given that Sunoco, LLC employees will only respond to routine small release events during the course of normal operation and would not be the primary responder during a catastrophic event on any of the RMP regulated processes.
6.0	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Future plans to improve safety are developed through several venues including the Employee Safety Suggestion program, Quarterly Safety Meetings, Process Hazard Analyses, Job Safety Analysis, and the BBS program. These safety action items are implemented through individual employees, employee committees or teams, and are supported by the site management team.   The following types of changes are planned:  

1.	Continue to train employees in all aspects of their job.
2.	Continue to consider and implement recommendations from Process Hazard Analyses where technologically feasible, and there is a proven benefit to the safety and/or operations of the process.
3.	Continue to consider and implement recommendations from Incident Investigations where technologically feasible, and there is a proven benefit to the safety and/or operations of the process.
4.	Review Hot Work policy regarding operations in the RMP regulated process areas including butane, anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide. 
5.	Evaluate documentation for test conducted on the ESV.
